newsitem.title: USA: U.S. AID prices $1.0 bln in debt for Israel.
newsitem.headline: U.S. AID prices $1.0 bln in debt for Israel.

text.p: The U.S. Agency for International Development (AID) Thursday priced $1.0 billion in a multi-tranche debt offering for Israel via Lehman Brothers and Merrill Lynch & Co Inc, dealers said.
The first part of the deal consisted of $533.144 million of fixed rate four-tranche debt via sole manager Lehman Brothers.
-Class A: $150 million in notes due August 15, 1999. The notes have a coupon of 6.125 and were priced at 99.7584 to yield 6.2167 percent or 3.4 basis points over comparable U.S. Treasuries.
-Class B: $150 million in notes due August 15, 2001. The notes have a 6.375 percent coupon at 99.4947 to yield 6.4965 or 10.5 basis points over U.S. Treasuries.
-Class B: $150 million in notes due August 15, 2001. The notes have a 6.375 percent coupon at 99.4947 to yield 6.4965 or 10.5 basis points over U.S. Treasuries.
-Class C: $150 million notes due August 15, 2003. The notes have a 6.625 percent coupon and were priced at 99.8882 to yield 6.646 or 13.2 basis points over U.S. Treasuries.
-Class D: $83.144 million notes due August 15, 2004. The notes have a 6.75 percent coupon and were priced at 99.9410 to yield 6.7603 percent or 18.6 basis points over Treasuries.
The second part of the deal, which was underwritten by Merrill Lynch & Co, consist of $471,904,955 (proceeds) in zero coupon notes via forty tranches.
The debt offering is rated AAA by Moody's Investors Service Inc and Standard & Poor's.
